chapter.pericope: Listen to God Rather Than Uttering Rash Vows

ul.li1: 1Ecclesiastes 5:1–20 in the English Bible is 4:17–5:19 in the Hebrew Bible Guard your steps when you go to the house of God;
ul.li2: draw near to listen rather than to offer a sacrifice of fools,
ul.li3: for they do not know that they are doing evil.
ul.li1: 2Do not be rash with your mouth,
ul.li2: and do not let your heart be quick to utter a word before God.
ul.li1: For God is in heaven, and you are on earth;
ul.li2: therefore, let your words be few.
ul.li1: 3For a dream comes with many cares,
ul.li2: and the voice of a fool with many words.
ul.li1: 4When you make a vow to God,
ul.li2: do not delay in fulfilling it,
ul.li1: for he takes no pleasureLiterally “there is no desire” in fools.
5It is better that you not vow
ul.li2: than that you vow and not fulfill it.
ul.li1: 6Do not let your mouth lead your flesh into sin,
ul.li2: and do not tell the messenger that it was a mistake.
ul.li1: Why anger God at your words,
ul.li2: so that he destroys the work of your hands?
ul.li1: 7For with many dreams come vanities and numerous words.

chapter.pericope: Powerful Bureaucrats Exploit the Helpless Poor

ul.li1: 8Do not be surprised if you see the poor being oppressed with violence
ul.li2: or do not see justice and righteousness in the province.
ul.li1: For one official is watched by a higher official,
ul.li2: and there are even higher officials over them!
ul.li1: 9The produce of the land is exploited by everyone;
ul.li2: even the king profits from the field of the poor!Literally “for the field is even worked for the king”

chapter.pericope: There is Never Enough Money to Satisfy

ul.li1: 10Whoever loves money is not satisfied with money,
ul.li2: and whoever loves wealth is not satisfied with profit.
except to see his wealth before it is spent.Literally “And what gain has its owner but to see it with his eyes?”
ul.li1: 12The sleep of the laborer is pleasant, whether he eats little or much,
ul.li2: but the wealth of the rich man does not allow him to rest.

chapter.p: 13There is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun: wealth hoardedLiterally “kept ” by its owner to his harm. 14That wealth was lost in a bad venture. Although he has borne a child, he has nothing to leave to him.Literally “he has nothing in his hand” 15Just as he came from his mother’s womb naked, he will departLiterally “return to go” just as he came; he will take nothing with him for his toil. 16This also is a grievous illness. Exactly as he came, so he will go. What profit does he gain for all his toil for the wind? 17Also, he eats in darkness all his days; he is frustrated in much sickness and resentment.
chapter.pericope: If You Have Wealth, Enjoy It as God Enables
chapter.p: 18Look! I have discovered what is good and fitting: to eat and to drink and to enjoyLiterally “to see goodness” all the fruit of the toil with which one toils under the sun during the number of the days of his life that God gives to him—for this is his lot.Or “fate” 19This indeed is a gift of God: everyone to whom God gives wealth and possessions, he also empowers him to enjoy them,Literally “to eat from it” to accept his lot, and to rejoice in the fruit of his toil. 20For he does not remember the brief days of his life, for God keeps his heart preoccupied with enjoyment of life.
